data.text: Contents
Introduction
The majority of clinical care should be provided on an individual patient- specific basis.

The supply and administration of medicines under Patient Group Directions (PGDs) should be reserved for those limited situations where this offers an advantage for patient care without compromising patient safety, and where it is consistent with appropriate professional relationships and accountability.
The supply and/or administration of a medicine under a PGD is NOT a prescription or prescribing.

PGDs are NOT intended as a substitute for individual prescribing where there is an opportunity in the care pathway for a medicine or medicines to be prescribed i.e. where an episode of care is planned, the need for a PGD must be carefully considered.

PGDS should be for supply/administration of POMS and supply of P medicines only. They should not be used for GSL Medicines at all and not for administration of P medicines. Please refer to MSEPO-20211 Discretionary medicines administration policy.
This policy is based on the MHRA document Patient Group Directions: who can use them and NICE guidance.

Any practice requiring a PGD that fails to comply with the criteria outlined in HSC 2000/026 (and any subsequent Statutory Instruments) falls outside of the Law and could result in criminal prosecution under the Medicines Act.
It is important that all staff involved with PGDs understand the scope and limitations of PGDs as well as the wider context into which they fit to ensure safe, effective services for patients.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Identify when a PGD is appropriate;
Provide information on how to write the PGD and how to get the PGD approved for use;
Provide information on how to implement the PGD into practice;
Renewal process.
This document is for individuals and organisations involved in developing and authorising PGDs (e.g. doctors, pharmacists, clinical governance leads).
All registered healthcare professionals supplying and / or administering medicines to patients via a PGD, specifically:
Registered Pharmacists;
Registered nurses;
Registered midwives;
Registered dietitians
Registered physiotherapists;
Registered occupational therapists;
Registered speech & language therapists;
Registered optometrists;
Registered orthoptists;
Registered orthoptists and prosthetists;
State registered chiropodists (podiatrists);
State registered physiotherapists;
State registered radiographers
State registered paramedics or qualified ambulance paramedics;
Dental hygienists and dental therapists.
Definitions

table_items.text: To give a medicine by either introduction into the body, whether by direct contact with the body or not, (e.g. orally or by injection) or by external application (e.g. application of an impregnated dressing)
The Trusts' electronic incident reporting systems (site specific)

General Sale List: These medicines can be sold with reasonable safety without the supervision or advice of a doctor or pharmacist and may be obtained through a variety of outlets (i.e. retail stores). All GSL medicines hold a valid UK product licence. There are regulations that restrict pack sizes and quantities to be classified as a GSL medicine

A medicine which falls within the definition of a medicinal product and which is granted a marketing authorisation by the MHRA when the safety, quality and efficacy of the product have been satisfactorily demonstrated by the license holder in accordance with EC directives 65/65
Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency
Medicines Information pharmacy service based at Broomfield Hospital
National Institute for Care and Health Excellence

A Patient Group Direction (PGD) is a written instruction for the supply or administration of a licensed medicine in a particular clinical situation. It must be drawn up by doctors, pharmacists and/or other professionals, and approved by the Medicines Assurance Group (group-wide). PGDs apply to patients who may not be individually named before treatment is required.

A Patient Specific Direction (PSD) is a written prescription from an independent prescriber (Doctor, Nurse or Pharmacist Independent prescriber) which instructs another healthcare professional to supply or administer a medicine to a specified patient.
Summary of Product Characteristics (available at www.medicines.org.uk)
To provide a medicine to a patient/carer for administration
To Take Away i.e. a prescription for medication to be dispensed for discharge from hospital.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
MSE Patient Safety Group is responsible for
Ensuring any concerns escalated by Medicines Assurance Group are appropriately managed corporately.
4.1.1 MSE Medicines Assurance Group (MAG)
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalate concerns to the Chief Nursing Officer or site Director of Nursing and Chief Medical Officer or Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the Patient Safety and Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning the safe use of medicines;
Ratification of all PGDs.
Acknowledging and taking action where needed in response to PGD reports issued by the Medicines Information (MI) Department.
4.1.2 Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Reviewing incidents reported and assessment of trends and themes;
Assisting in the development and review of medicines management policies, guidelines and procedures;
Managing any site-specific issues concerning site-specific PGD processes;
Reporting into Medicines Assurance Group (MAG) as appropriate for the subject material.
4.1.3 Pharmacy Directorate Board
Ensuring pharmacy departmental SOPs relating to PGDs are maintained and adhered to in accordance with current guidance and legislation.
4.1.4 Divisional Governance Groups
Ensuring clinical oversight, appropriate monitoring and approval of PGDs in use, and proposed to be used, within their clinical areas;
Reviewing new incident reports and taking action with respect to service delivery;
Ensuring attendance and engagement at the site Medication Optimisation and Safety Group;
Ensuring engagement of directorate/divisional staff with the pharmacy PGD management service in line with this policy.
Acknowledging and taking action where needed in response to PGD reports issued by the Medicines Information department.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust Duties Are:
4.2.1 Chief Executive
As the Trust Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for:
Ensuring each Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
4.2.2 Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site Directors of Nursing that the service is operating effectively;
Organisational group-wide approval for all group-wide PGDs that have been authorised when acting as Clinical Governance Lead (see appendix 3 for the sign off on PGD template);
Overseeing the implementation of group-wide non-medical prescribing in preference to the use of PGDs where possible;
Ensuring any escalated PGD issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
4.2.3 Chief Medical Officer is responsible for
Ensuring any escalated PGD issues involving medical staff are appropriately managed corporately.
4.2.4 Chief Pharmacist
Signing approved PGDs on behalf of the MAG;
Ensuring the pharmacy services for PGD management;

Ensuring that there is policy compliance by pharmacy services and liaising with the site Pharmacy Head of Department that the service is operating effectively, specifically Broomfield hospital pharmacy service as host site for PGD management;
Ensuring that site pharmacy services has uploaded current PGDs to the intranet for each site in line with this policy.
4.2.5 Site Director of Nursing
Organisational site approval for all site-specific PGDs that have been authorised when acting as Clinical Governance Lead (see appendix 3 for the sign off on PGD template);
Overseeing the implementation of site-specific non-medical prescribing in preference to the use of PGDs where possible.
4.2.6 Site Medical Director
Ensuring each Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
4.2.7 Senior Clinical Nurse or relevant professional lead for the service
Provision of specialist professional advice and support including provision of information on service delivery within their clinical area;
On-going professional advice and support for practitioners when the PGD is in practice, during audit and review of the PGD;
Ensuring competence of staff within their service that uses PGDs;
Ensuring the PGD has been developed according to correct organisational procedures and that those involved in the development of the direction are competent to do so;
Ensuring the PGD is fit for purpose for the care being delivered to patients in that particular area/service;
Working within locally agreed timeframes to ensure timely development and approval of the PGD.
Ensuring PGD users are competent which may include using the Competence Framework Assessment Document for training staff (appendix 4);
Signing off competent staff to use the PGD.
4.2.8 MSE Lead PGD Pharmacist (Medicines Information Pharmacist Lead)
Reporting audit results and monitoring to relevant governance groups and to MAG as required;
Ensuring there is a need for a PGD identified and the objectives of the PGD can be met safely;
Checking whether there is a national PGD already in existence that can be adopted;
Ensuring the written PGD complies with legal requirements;
Liaising between the author of the PGD, relevant site specialist clinical pharmacist (if applicable) and the Medicines Assurance Group during the ratification process;
Working within locally agreed timeframes to ensure timely development and approval of the PGD;
On-going provision of pharmaceutical advice and support when the PGD is in practice and during/following audit and review;
Contacting PGD authors to advise them to review PGD every 2 years;
Maintaining the published PGDs directory by uploading newly approved PGDs and remove expired PGDs on the Trust intranet;
Keeping complete records of all current PGDs for all sites;
Storage of all signed PGDs at Broomfield Hospital Medicines Information pharmacy service, for all sites.
4.2.9 Pharmacist

If a site specialist clinical pharmacist does not exist for the area requiring a PGD then the Principal Pharmacist with divisional responsibility will delegate to the most appropriate pharmacist to fulfil the site specialist pharmacist role.
Provision of pharmaceutical advice and support prior to and during PGD development;
On-going provision of pharmaceutical advice and support when the PGD is in practice and during/following audit and review;
Ensuring all content of the PGD is legal and clinically accurate;
Ensuring that arrangements for medication supplied as take away (TTA) packs are appropriately labelled and procured in a legal and timely manner, in line with site pharmacy procedures for TTA packs;
Ensuring that PGDs are updated if there are any changes to the licensing of the drug for which the PGD exists either at review stage or
earlier if necessary.
4.2.10 Clinical lead/Consultant Signatory

Liaising with the PGD author, site specialist clinical pharmacist and lead nurse of the area to determine whether a PGD is a clinically appropriate method to administer and supply medication for a given clinical situation;
Ensuring the PGD is clinically accurate and that local and national guidelines have been considered with reference to their medical speciality;
Giving appropriate advice on action to be taken in the case of cautions and contraindications;
Ensuring that appropriate follow up advice to the patient is correct and safe;
Making the PGD author, pharmacist and additional signatories aware of any changes in clinical practice or guidelines that may necessitate a review;
Ensuring provision of medical advice to excluded patients in a timely manner;
Working within locally agreed timeframes to ensure timely development and approval of the PGD.
4.2.11 PGD author
Ensuring there is a full clinical need for PGD that will benefit patient care;
Completing the PGD Proposal form;
Completing the PGD using the template within this policy;
Ensuring the written PGD complies with legal requirements;
Ensuring the development, submission and implementation of PGDs is carried out in accordance with this policy;
Regularly auditing the use of the PGD and ensuring the PGD is reviewed in line with this policy.
Identifying any newly responsible staff members to the Lead PGD Pharmacist (Medicines Information Pharmacist Lead) (hosted by Broomfield Hospital) if author leaves current role;
Working within locally agreed timeframes to ensure timely development and approval of the PGD.
4.2.12 Registered Healthcare professional using the PGD
Maintaining registered membership of their profession and acting within their appropriate code of professional conduct;
Undertaking the training specified in the PGD and successfully completing the competencies to enable appropriate application of the PGD;
Being aware of any changes to the management of the medication listed in the PGD that may render the PGD out of date;
Keeping up-to-date with continued professional development and work within the limitations of the individual's scope of practice and within the parameters of the PGD;
Using the current approved PGD and ensuring that it is in date;
Participating in audit and the PGD review process as necessary;
Re-reading and re-signing the PGD every 3 years after it has been
reviewed.
Trust Bank Staff and Locum agency staff may work under a PGD provided that all of the criteria listed above can be demonstrated.
PGD development
A licensed medicine to be used within its licensed indication can be used in a PGD.
Exemptions and special considerations to medicines within a PGD:
Unlicensed medicines cannot be used in a PGD. Only medicines with a UK Marketing Authorisation can be supplied and/or administered under a PGD.
Use of licensed medicines outside of licensed indications i.e. off label is allowed in PGD legislation but must represent accepted best practice and must have MAG approval for this use.

PGDS should be for supply/administration of POMs and supply of P medicines only. They should not be used for GSL Medicines at all and not for administration of P medicines. Please refer to MSEPO-20211 Discretionary medicines administration policy. Legacy PGDs which contain GSL and P medicines will be phased out and replaced by the discretionary medicines administration policy framework.
Medicines used in clinical trials cannot be included in a PGD.
5.2.1  Controlled drugs cannot be used in a PGD except:
Morphine and Diamorphine — only for use by registered nurses or registered pharmacists in the immediate, necessary treatment of a sick or injured person (not for the treatment of addiction);
Midazolam;
All drugs listed in Schedule 4 of the Misuse of Drugs Regulations 2001 (these are mainly benzodiazepines), except anabolic steroids;
All drugs listed in Schedule 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Regulations 2001 (i.e. low-strength opiates, such as codeine);
PGDs involving an antimicrobial must have a microbiologist, antimicrobial specialist pharmacist or public health specialist with appropriate expertise involved in their development;
‘Black triangle' medicines must be clearly identified and must only be used in a PGD if such use is exceptional and is supported by current best practice;
PGDs are not appropriate for management of long-term conditions;
PGDs are not suitable for situations with a high usage of temporary staff – as relevant competency cannot be reliably demonstrated;
PGDs are not suitable where it will be difficult to monitor the use of the PGD.
To comply with the law, PGDs must contain the following information:
The period for which the direction is to have effect;
The name of the Trust site (or ‘all sites') to which the PGD applies;
The date the PGD comes into force and the date it expires;
A description of the medicine(s) to which the PGD applies;
The class of health care professional who may supply or administer the medicine;
The signature of a doctor or dentist, as appropriate, and a pharmacist;
The signature of an appropriate health organisation;
The clinical condition, or situation, to which the PGD applies;
A description of patients excluded from treatment under the PGD;
A description of the circumstances under which further advice must be sought from a doctor (or dentist, as appropriate) and arrangements made for referral;

Details of appropriate dosage and maximum total dosage, quantity, pharmaceutical form and strength, route and frequency of administration, and minimum or maximum period over which the medicine must be administered;
Relevant warnings, including potential adverse reactions;
Details of any necessary follow-up action;
A statement of records to be kept for audit purposes.
PGDs must be drawn up by a multi-disciplinary group involving a doctor, a pharmacist and a representative of any professional group expected to supply medicines under the PGD.
All Trust PGDs are reviewed and approved by MAG.

The Senior Clinical Nurse, or senior registered professional if the PGD is not used by nursing staff, is designated with the responsibility to ensure that only fully competent, qualified and trained professionals operate within the direction of a PGD. This responsibility may be delegated to an appropriately trained deputy, usually the PGD author, where appropriate.

All professions must act within their appropriate Code of Professional Conduct and be aware that using a PGD does not remove inherent professional obligations or accountability. The act of supply and/or administration cannot be delegated to another health professional under a PGD.
Is a PGD appropriate?
Assessment of a clinical need for a PGD

The following national guidance information must be followed to aid assessment of whether there is a clinical need for a PGD. The Trust will not usually support a PGD where nationally accepted alternatives are more appropriate:
To PGD or not to PGD – that is the question.
(NHS Specialist Pharmacy Service).
Available at: https://www.sps.nhs.uk/articles/to-pgd-or-not-to-pgd-that-is- the-question/
Patient group directions and patient specific directions.
(British Medical Association)
Available at: https://www.bma.org.uk/advice/employment/gp- practices/service-provision/prescribing/patient-group-directions
Specific Medication Summaries of Product Characteristics (SPCs) Available at: www.medicines.org.uk
The service wishing to produce a PGD must first consider:
Is the PGD the most appropriate method of providing treatment for the group of patients in the defined clinical situation?
Is there a clearly defined gap in service that a PGD can address without compromising patient safety?
Is the recommended use included in the PGD consistent with the SPC, NICE and locally agreed guidance?
Are appropriately labelled packs of medication available as TTA packs? And if not are these possible?
Is there a safe, locked storage area for medicines?
Is the storage room/fridge temperature controlled monitored?

The site specialist clinical pharmacists may be contacted by the MI pharmacy team to discuss the appropriateness for the PGD and whether appropriately labelled packs of the medication to be supplied are readily available in the specific sites.
PGD writing process

Once discussed with the directorate clinical leads and specialist pharmacist that a PGD is appropriate, a proposal form must be completed (appendix 2) and sent to the Lead PGD Pharmacist (Medicines Information Pharmacist Lead). It must be ensured that the proposal has directorate governance support before submission.

Once the Lead PGD Pharmacist has reviewed the proposal form and agrees that the PGD as appropriate, a blank PGD template will be sent to the author (appendix 3). If a national PGD has been published this can be used instead of appendix 3 and the PGD approval process in section 8 should be followed.
Requirements of a PGD are summarised in section 5.
PGD approval process
For approval of new PGDs, see Appendix
For PGD Renewal and Review, see sections 12 and
Documented records of accepting or rejecting a renewal or proposal are held in the Medicines information department at Broomfield Hospital, in line with pharmacy departmental procedures.
Authorisation
Paper Authorisation

All PGDs must be signed by the following members of the multi- disciplinary group involved in the development i.e. a doctor, pharmacist and senior representative of the professional group(s) expected to supply medicines under the PGD to approve the content.
All new PGDs must be approved by the Medicines Assurance Group (MAG), prior to use within the Trust.
Following approval, as above, all PGDs must be signed by the designated Clinical Governance Lead authorising the PGD for use within the organisation which is the Trust's Chief Pharmacist.
Electronic Authorisation: Use of electronic signature.
The following national guidance must be followed when using an electronic signature·
An electronic signature must be linked uniquely to an individual and under their sole control.
The standards laid down for electronic prescribing should be observed,
i.e.:
The final document must be securely protected and the signature cannot be lifted out e.g. must be in a protected pdf format rather than a word processed document.
A signatory can authorise a PGD by signing into their organisational email address and sending an email to mse.medicineinfo@nhs.net  (Medicines Information Team) to confirm their authorisation.
A copy of this email authorisation will be kept with the master copy of the PGD for reference.
The PGD will state “Email on file” alongside the names and job titles of all involved. The date of authorisation will be annotated under this statement.
See Appendix 8 for process.
Implementation of the PGD into practice

The PGD will be uploaded to the specific site's Intranet/Hub once it has been authorised and completed and ready to use. Until this has been done the PGD must not be used. Medicines information pharmacy team (hosted by Broomfield Hospital) will contact the author once the PGD is uploaded.

The role of the registered health professional in the use of the PGD is not compulsory and they must exercise professional and personal judgement as to whether to accept the responsibility that this role places on them. All staff must acknowledge that the interests and safety of every patient is paramount.
Training and competencies must be undertaken and maintained, see Training requirements chapter and appendix

Records of the completed and signed legal PGDs are held centrally at the MSE Medicines Information department at Broomfield Hospital, for all sites. This will be in line with pharmacy departmental procedures.
Administering or supplying medication using a PGD
Please refer to the relevant sections of the MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines and MSEPO-21128 Administration of medicines policy.
Inpatients:
Record the medication in the medical notes (or equivalent) and on the STAT side of the Drug Prescription Chart/Electronic prescribing drug chart, or as directed within the PGD;
State the date, drug name, dose, route and ‘'administered under PGD''
Sign for administration and record any expiry dates and batch numbers as relevant as per PGD.
TTA supply:
Select the appropriate TTA pre-labelled pack as per the directions on the PGD, checking expiry date;
Complete the patient name and date of supply section on the label;
Complete the dose, frequency and duration on the label if left blank as per directions on PGD;
Under no circumstances can the TTA pack label be otherwise amended or dose units added or removed from the box. This is illegal;
A second signature must be obtained as described in MSEPO-21144 Discharge TTA medication policy (unless specified otherwise in the individual PGD document);
Record the medication supplied in the medical notes (or equivalent), including batch number and expiry date for vaccines and ‘supplied against
PGD';
Ensure the patient is given a patient information leaflet (PIL);
Replacement TTA packs are to be requested via pharmacy distribution.
Any medication errors or near misses must be reported via the Trust incident and near miss reporting system (DCIQ).
Under no circumstances can the administration or supply of medication under a PGD be delegated to another healthcare professional.
Renewal
The PGD expires 3 years from the publication date.
An expired PGD is illegal and can no longer be used.

The PGD author is responsible for organising the review of the PGD. This must commence  months before the PGD is due to expire. The MI pharmacy team must email the PGD author at least 12 months before the expiry date as a reminder.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. during an organisational or service transition) an expiry extension can be authorised for no longer than one year. The total valid period should not exceed 3 years from the date the PGD was authorised. Appendix 7 needs to be completed for any PGD extension.
Review process
The PGD needs to be reviewed by the PGD author, clinical lead/consultant and the senior nurse / professional for that area of practice.
The review must include:
An assessment of whether the PGD remains the most effective way of providing the relevant services;

Assessment of whether there have been any changes to the clinical content of the PGD. This may necessitate a literature search in certain instances. Any changes in guidance, licensed indications or dosing recommendations must be noted, and updates made where appropriate;
Any changes to a PGD must be highlighted on a draft version of the PGD and changes stated on the renewal form (appendix 6).
The PGD is submitted to the Lead PGD Pharmacist with a PGD renewal submission form (appendix 6) once the review is completed.

All PGD renewals are sent to MAG, for ratification and then the MI Pharmacy team (based at Broomfield Hospital) will send back to authors for signatures. It is the responsibility of the author to collect required signatures. Please note, the last signatures to be collected if electronic signatures are being used should be that of the Chief Pharmacist.
The PGD author, Lead PGD Pharmacist, representative of lead nurse / professional for that area of practice or MAG member may request early review of a PGD in response to:
Changes in relevant legislation;
Updated local or national guidance, such as that issued by NHS Specialist Pharmacy Service;
Drug safety updates issued by the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) or equivalent body;
Updates to the SPC;
Changes to the Trust formulary.
A review must be undertaken, prior to reauthorisation of the PGD, to determine that the PGD is being used lawfully and appropriately.

Requests to re-authorise a PGD following review cannot be considered if there is no accompanying information. This may result in a delay in re- authorising the PGD and may necessitate the PGD being removed from practice.
Appendix 5 includes questions the PGD author is required to complete before re-authorisation can occur.
Review of the PGD must include consideration of:
Is there an up-to-date list of staff permitted to practice under the PGD?
Have any incidents occurred relating to the use of the PGD?
Did incidents that have occurred get recorded via DCIQ and investigated? What was the outcome of these?
Do all staff practising under the PGD have a current training record?
Do all staff practising under the PGD have access to the PGD document?
Is supply of medicines (where applicable) carried out in accordance with the relevant Trust Medication Policy?
PGD Standards and key performance indicators
The PGD system is measured by assessing a range of indicators:
All new PGDs have a proven genuine need and submission for the PGD made via the correct process;
All PGDs will start their review process 2 years after approval date and be re-signed within 3 years;
All PGDs have evidence of audit of use as detailed within the policy;
All PGDs are approved and available for use within the time frame indicated without undue delay to service provision;
All key individuals act within the roles and responsibilities as listed in section 7 of the PGD.
Training Requirements

Relevant staff wishing to administer or supply medication against a PGD must undertake training and be assessed by the senior clinical nurse or relevant professional lead, or nominated deputy, as competent prior to using the PGD. They must also ensure they have read this policy.
To be deemed competent the relevant member of staff must be able to:
Demonstrate understanding of the indications and contraindications for the medicine;
Demonstrate knowledge of the appropriate use of the medicine;
Demonstrate knowledge of the appropriate client group for the medicine;
Demonstrate knowledge of the appropriate storage of the medicine;
Demonstrate skill in the administration of the medicine;
Demonstrate that they are able to advise patients about the indications and contraindications for the medicine and self-management following administration;
Demonstrate knowledge of anaphylaxis and other adverse reactions;
Maintain appropriate records;
Demonstrate knowledge of adverse incident reporting arrangements.
Competency assessment can be in the form of role play or supervised practice. This will be clearly documented.

The competency assessment framework template (appendix 4) must be used as a guide and adapted to local practice. Services must use the template to add in questions relevant to the drug and disease that the PGD is covering.

The senior clinical nurse or relevant registered professional lead* is responsible for ensuring their staff have had a competency assessment and have been signed off on the individual authorisation form for each PGD. (*This can be delegated to another member of staff, who is competent in the use of the PGD).

A master copy of signatures of staff members who are competent to use the PGD must be kept within the relevant clinical department. A second individual copy is kept in the staff's personal file with a copy of the competency assessment.
The competency assessment must be documented and must occur at least every 3 years (in line with PGD renewal).

Pharmacy staff directly involved in the management of PGDs are trained by the Lead Pharmacist Medicines Information. They are the link specialist for supporting pharmacists in making informed decisions and providing appropriate advice when working with clinicians or nurses to develop a PGD's.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via Pharmacy Medicines Information Service, hosted by Broomfield Hospital, for all sites, or via the site Specialist Clinical Pharmacist for the speciality.
NOTE: PGDs can be only be implemented once the PGDs have been uploaded to the site specific intranet.

Appendix 5: Patient Group Directions Summary Sheet
Patient Group Directions (PGD) Summary Sheet
What are PGDs?

Patient group directions (PGDs) provide a legal framework that allows the supply and/or administration of a specified medicine(s), by named, authorised, registered health professionals, to a pre-defined group of patients needing prophylaxis or treatment for a condition described in the PGD, without the need for a prescription or an instruction from a prescriber.
Supplying and/or administering medicines under PGDs should be reserved for situations in which this offers an advantage for patient care without compromising patient safety.
Before practising under a PGD, health professionals should ensure that they:
have undertaken the necessary initial training and continuing professional development;
have been assessed as competent and authorised to practise by the provider organisation;
are using a copy of the most recent and in date final signed version of the PGD;
have read and understand the context and content of the PGD.
When practising under a PGD, health professionals should:
not delegate their responsibility (e.g. to another member of staff);
ensure that they can determine that the patient meets the inclusion criteria as set out in the PGD;
ensure that they can determine that no exclusion criteria apply;
discuss alternative options for treating the patient's condition, when appropriate;
assess each individual patient's circumstances and preferences;
recognise when signposting or referral to another health professional or service is needed, as specified in the PGD;
understand relevant information about the medicine(s) included in the PGD, such as:
a) how to administer the medicine;
b) how the medicine acts within the body;
c) dosage calculations;
d) potential adverse effects and how to manage them;
e) drug interactions, precautions and contraindications;
f) storage requirements, including maintenance of the ‘cold chain';
g) follow-up arrangements;
h) being able to advise the patient or their carer about the medicine(s), as appropriate.
Document as specified in the patient's notes and/or medication chart.
When supplying a medicine(s), provide an appropriately labelled ‘TTA pack'. Health professionals must never split packs.
Ensure that the patient receives a manufacturer's patient information leaflet with each medicine
